questions.guidance_text: Enter the complete legal name of the company planning the public offering. This should match the name in your incorporation documents and draft prospectus. For listed companies, use the name as registered with stock exchanges.

Provide the registered office address of the company. This address will be used for all official correspondence regarding the insurance policy. Include complete details with building name, street, city, state, and PIN code.
questions.placeholder: e.g., Tower A, 10th Floor, Cyber City, DLF Phase 2, Gurugram, Haryana - 122002

questions.guidance_text: Select the primary industry sector of your company. This helps insurers assess the specific risks associated with your business model and the public offering. Choose the category that generates the majority of your revenue.

Enter the number of years your company has been operating continuously under current management. Longer operational history typically indicates stability and may result in better premium rates. Count from the date of incorporation or major restructuring.

List any previous names your company operated under, with dates of change. This is important for liability coverage continuity and helps insurers track company history. Include mergers, acquisitions, or rebranding details.
questions.placeholder: e.g., ABC Software Pvt Ltd (2015-2020), ABC Tech Solutions Ltd (2020-2023)

questions.guidance_text: Select the date when your company was officially incorporated with the Registrar of Companies. This date is mentioned on your Certificate of Incorporation and helps establish the company's legal existence timeline.
Enter the city and state where your company is incorporated. For Indian companies, this is the ROC jurisdiction mentioned in your CIN. This determines applicable regulations and legal framework.

options: No - Private Company going for IPO
questions.guidance_text: Indicate whether your company is currently listed on any stock exchange or is a private company planning its Initial Public Offering (IPO). Listed companies going for Follow-on Public Offering (FPO) have different risk profiles than IPO companies.

questions.question_text: Stock Exchanges Where Listed/Planning to List
questions.guidance_text: Select all stock exchanges where your company is currently listed or planning to list through this public offering. Main board listings have different requirements than SME platforms. Multiple listings may require broader coverage.

This is the maximum amount the insurer will pay for all claims during the policy period. For IPOs, this typically ranges from 5-10% of the offering size. Higher limits provide better protection against securities litigation but increase premium costs. You can enter the amount in lakhs or crores (e.g., 50,00,000 or 5,00,00,000).

The deductible is the amount you'll pay out-of-pocket before insurance coverage kicks in for each claim. Higher deductibles reduce premium but increase your financial exposure. Choose based on your company's risk tolerance and financial capacity. You can enter the amount in lakhs or crores (e.g., 50,00,000 or 5,00,00,000).

Coverage should ideally start before the draft prospectus filing date to cover the entire offering process. Most companies start coverage 30-60 days before the expected IPO launch to cover pre-IPO activities and roadshows.

POSI policies typically run for 6-7 years from the IPO date as per SEBI regulations. The extended period covers potential claims arising from prospectus misstatements that may surface years after the offering.

questions.question_text: Total Gross Assets of North American Subsidiaries
questions.guidance_text: If you have subsidiaries in USA or Canada, enter their total asset value in INR. US exposure significantly increases liability risk due to their litigation-friendly environment and requires special coverage considerations.

questions.question_text: Are shares traded on any US Stock Exchange?
questions.guidance_text: Indicate if your company's shares are listed or traded on NYSE, NASDAQ, or any other US exchange. US listing dramatically increases securities litigation risk and requires specialized coverage with higher premiums.

questions.question_text: Do you issue American Depository Receipts (ADRs)?
questions.guidance_text: ADRs allow US investors to buy shares in foreign companies. Even unsponsored ADRs can create US jurisdiction exposure. This significantly impacts coverage needs and premium as it opens potential for US-based litigation.

This covers your directors/officers serving on boards of other companies at your request. Important if your executives serve on subsidiary boards, joint venture companies, or industry associations. Extends protection beyond your company.

List companies where your directors serve on boards, including company name, director name, position, ownership percentage, and whether that company has D&O insurance. This helps assess additional exposure and coverage needs.
questions.placeholder: e.g., ABC Subsidiary Ltd - Mr. John Doe, Director, 100% owned, Has D&O coverage

questions.question_text: Any ongoing acquisitions, mergers, or tender offers?
questions.guidance_text: Disclose any M&A activities your company is currently pursuing. These transactions can significantly impact valuation and create additional disclosure obligations that affect securities liability risk.

questions.question_text: Are there proposals for your company to be acquired?
questions.guidance_text: Indicate if there are any offers or discussions about your company being acquired. This could affect the public offering plans and creates unique liability scenarios that need special coverage consideration.

questions.question_text: Planning a public offering within next 12 months?
questions.guidance_text: Confirm the type of public offering planned. IPOs have highest risk, followed by Follow-on Public Offerings (FPO) and Offer for Sale (OFS). Rights issues have relatively lower securities litigation risk.

questions.question_text: Changes in Board or Senior Management
questions.guidance_text: List any changes in directors, CEO, CFO, or other key executives in the past 12 months. Include names, positions, dates, and reasons for departure. Management stability is a key factor in assessing governance risk.
questions.placeholder: e.g., Mr. XYZ, CFO, Resigned 01/01/2025 - Personal reasons; Replaced by Ms. ABC on 15/01/2025

questions.question_text: Has D&O insurance ever been refused or cancelled?
questions.guidance_text: Disclose if any insurer has ever declined, cancelled, or refused to renew D&O or POSI coverage for your company. Be honest - insurers share this information. If yes, you'll need to explain the circumstances.

questions.question_text: Do you currently have D&O Liability Insurance?
questions.guidance_text: Indicate if you have an active Directors & Officers liability policy. POSI is typically purchased in addition to regular D&O coverage to specifically cover public offering risks. Existing D&O coverage shows good governance practices.

questions.question_text: Any notices given under current/prior D&O policies?
questions.guidance_text: Disclose if you've notified insurers about potential claims or circumstances that might lead to claims under any D&O policy. This includes precautionary notices about investigations, lawsuits, or regulatory actions.

questions.question_text: Any claims paid under D&O insurance?
questions.guidance_text: Indicate if any claims have been paid out under your D&O policies in the past. Include settlements, legal defense costs, or judgments. Past claims indicate higher risk but don't automatically disqualify coverage.

questions.question_text: Pending or past claims against directors/officers?
questions.guidance_text: Disclose any lawsuits, regulatory proceedings, or investigations involving your directors or officers, whether ongoing or resolved. Include shareholder disputes, SEBI investigations, or criminal proceedings. Full disclosure is legally required.

Provide complete details of any claims, lawsuits, or proceedings mentioned above. Include dates, parties involved, allegations, current status, and financial impact. Transparency helps insurers properly assess and price the risk.
questions.placeholder: e.g., SEBI investigation for insider trading, Started: Jan 2024, Status: Ongoing, No financial penalty yet

questions.guidance_text: For claims-made policies, this date determines how far back the coverage extends for past acts. Typically set to company incorporation date or when you first purchased D&O insurance. Earlier dates provide broader protection.

If you have/had D&O or POSI coverage, provide insurer names, policy periods, coverage limits, and premium paid. This helps ensure seamless coverage transition and may qualify you for better terms based on claims-free history.
questions.placeholder: e.g., ABC Insurance Ltd, Period: 01/04/2023-31/03/2024, Limit: ₹10 Cr, Premium: ₹15 lakhs

questions.question_text: Aware of circumstances that might lead to claims?
questions.guidance_text: Critically important question - disclose ANY circumstances that could reasonably give rise to a claim. This includes regulatory inquiries, internal investigations, whistleblower complaints, or media allegations. Non-disclosure can void coverage.

Describe any circumstances that might lead to claims, even if uncertain. Include regulatory scrutiny, accounting irregularities, employment disputes, or governance issues. Early disclosure protects your coverage for these matters.
questions.placeholder: Provide detailed description of any circumstances that could potentially lead to a claim

questions.guidance_text: Share any additional information that helps underwriters assess your risk profile. Include positive factors like strong governance practices, independent board composition, compliance certifications, or risk management systems that reduce liability exposure.
questions.placeholder: e.g., We have 5 independent directors, quarterly compliance audits, and ISO 27001 certification

questions.guidance_text: If renewing or switching insurers, provide your current policy number, insurer name, expiry date, and premium. This helps insurers offer competitive quotes and ensure no coverage gaps during transition.
questions.placeholder: e.g., Policy No: D&O/2024/12345, Insurer: XYZ Insurance, Expiry: 31/03/2025, Premium: ₹20 lakhs

questions.guidance_text: Upload audited financial statements for the last 3 years in PDF format. These help insurers assess financial stability and growth trajectory. For IPO companies, include any restated financials prepared for the offering.

If available, upload the DRHP or draft prospectus. This is the key document insurers review to assess disclosure quality and potential liability. Even preliminary drafts help in getting accurate quotes.
Upload the board resolution authorizing purchase of POSI coverage. This demonstrates proper corporate approval and governance. Some insurers require this before binding coverage.
If you have existing D&O coverage, upload the current policy document. This helps insurers understand your existing protection and structure the POSI policy to complement it without gaps or overlaps.
